Blurb
Overview
This practical module is the first experience of life science practical and quantitative skills for students and aims to provide applied and theoretical experience in basic practical techniques currently used across the Life Sciences disciplines. The module is designed so that students acquire a wide range of experimental, analytical & problem-solving skills that will be required for other practical modules throughout the degree and will begin to lay the foundations for their Year 3 research project and of subsequent careers. It aims to develop good lab practices, experimental design and interpretation of results, using fundamental quantitative skills to handle and analyse corresponding data that has been acquired by the students.

The module comprises of physical practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and quantitative workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand methodologies, undertake research science safely and apply research methods to coaligned theoretical content. They will also be able to communicate their research findings. This practical will be assessed via three methods: continual assessment to assess understanding of practical skills (experimental, technical and computational/quantitative statistics), a practical skills observational assessment to improve research and experimental skills and a written scientific abstract to assess overall understanding and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To enhance students' practical skills in key experimental techniques, data collection, data manipulation/visualisation, interpretation, and analyses.

2. To develop a further understanding of theoretical knowledge in the context of practical skills and exercises.

3. To demonstrate the relevance of practical skills across all biological disciplines and explain the importance of observing good laboratory practice.

4. To develop the essential quantitative, numerical, and digital skills required to be competent Life Scientists.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This is the first practical module that students will take in the School of Life Sciences. The variety of experimental, quantitative and transferable skills that students acquire will be required for future practical modules that they will take in Year 1 Semester 2, during Year 2 and will prepare them for their Year 3 research project and for their subsequent career. This module is designed to teach the basic multidisciplinary skills required in the field of life sciences, provide an understanding of basic lab practice and safety and to allow application of theoretical knowledge to solve practical challenges. It will be taught through a combination of lectures, practical sessions, workshops and self directed learning.

This practical will be assessed via three methods: continual assessment to assess understanding of practical skills (experimental, technical and computational/quantitative statistics), a practical skills observational assessment to improve research and experimental skills and a written scientific abstract to assess overall understanding and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Introduction to practical & experimental skills within Life Sciences. Covering topics such as the use of basic laboratory equipment, practical skills, scientific measurements, data handling, health & safety and ethics.

Topic 2: Handling & measurements of Model Organisms. Covering topics such as handling of model organisms such as zebra fish, microscopy and application to health and disease

Topic 3: Measurements at the molecular level. Covering topics such as stock concentration preparation, serial dilutions, standard curve creation & calculations

Topic 4: Microbiological techniques. Covering topics such as Aseptic technique, antibiotic resistance, bacterial handling and microbial identification.

Topic 5: Media Preparation & Acids & Bases. Covering topics such as pH buffering, creation of media and solutions

Topic 6: Mutation & Cell Viability. Covering topics such as dose response (LD50s), dilution, concentration calculations and toxicology testing.

Topic 7: Protein concentration determination. Covering topics such as protein solution preparation, determination of unknown concentrations, Bradford/protein assays, spectrophotometry

Topic 8: Introduction to Cell Biology & cell surface interactions. Covering topics such as molecular interactions and multicellularity, plate assays; Microscopy: counting cell populations, examining cells and surface charge;

Topic 9: Histology. Covering topics such as muscle histology, tissue staining, visualisation and microscopy


Statistical, data interpretation & data visualisation skills to be implemented may include topics such as:

Topic 1: Introduction to Excel and R Coding

Topic 2: Manipulating numbers & data

Topic 3: Units and Conversion.

Topic 4: Molarities, concentrations and serial dilutions.

Topic 5: Linear equations and linear regression.

Topic 5: Non-linear equations and logarithms,

Topic 6: Descriptive Statistics

Topic 7: Hypothesis building and testing (Inferential Statistics)
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also e corporate application of numeracy & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies. All asynchronous content will be accompanied by formative, dynamic quizzes that allow students to practice the practical application of quantitative skills encountered.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 5

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. These comprise of multiple sessions of active learning which focus on the assessment tasks/real world research, data analysis and simulations.
Attendance Recorded: Yes


The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Life Sciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated.



Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.



Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the life sciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.



Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The competency assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills, continual learning and development and appreciation of the principles of good lab practice, ethics and safety. Continual assessment will allow students to implement theoretical, numerical and data handling skills to applied scientific problems that have been covered within the practical. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific abstract is highly authentic for practical application and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.



Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.



Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.



Global citizenship: Life Sciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:

1. Continuous assessment in the form of portfolio consisting of post lab online tests (weighting 40%) which assesses the student's relevant academic knowledge, as well as enquiry-based analytical skills (Research connected teaching, Digital Fluency - Liverpool Curriculum). Open book and resit not allowed.

2. Practical skills assessment (30%) based on skills acquired in practical sessions, formative feedback given immediately and verbally, multiple attempts throughout semester (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

3. Abstract writing (weighting 30%) based on the skills to evaluate and interpret and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

The mode of assessments include:

1. Continuous assessment in the form of portfolio consisting of post lab online tests (weighting 40%) which assesses the student's relevant academic knowledge, as well as enquiry-based analytical skills (Research connected teaching, Digital Fluency - Liverpool Curriculum). Open book and resit not allowed.

2. Practical skills assessment (30%) based on skills acquired in practical sessions, formative feedback given immediately and verbally, multiple attempts throughout semester (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

3. Abstract writing (weighting 30%) based on the skills to evaluate and interpret and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
This practical module is the first experience of life science practical and quantitative skills for students and aims to provide applied and theoretical experience in basic practical techniques currently used across the Life Sciences disciplines. The module is designed so that students acquire a wide range of experimental, analytical & problem-solving skills that will be required for other practical modules throughout the degree and will begin to lay the foundations for their Year 3 research project and of subsequent careers. It aims to develop good lab practices, experimental design and interpretation of results, using fundamental quantitative skills to handle and analyse corresponding data that has been acquired by the students.

The module comprises of physical practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and quantitative workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand methodologies, undertake research science safely and apply research methods to coaligned theoretical content. They will also be able to communicate their research findings. This practical will be assessed via three methods: continual assessment to assess understanding of practical skills (experimental, technical and computational/quantitative statistics), a practical skills observational assessment to improve research and experimental skills and a written scientific abstract to assess overall understanding and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To enhance students' practical skills in key experimental techniques, data collection, data manipulation/visualisation, interpretation, and analyses.

2. To develop a further understanding of theoretical knowledge in the context of practical skills and exercises.

3. To demonstrate the relevance of practical skills across all biological disciplines and explain the importance of observing good laboratory practice.

4. To develop the essential quantitative, numerical, and digital skills required to be competent Life Scientists.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This is the first practical module that students will take in the School of Life Sciences. The variety of experimental, quantitative and transferable skills that students acquire will be required for future practical modules that they will take in Year 1 Semester 2, during Year 2 and will prepare them for their Year 3 research project and for their subsequent career. This module is designed to teach the basic multidisciplinary skills required in the field of life sciences, provide an understanding of basic lab practice and safety and to allow application of theoretical knowledge to solve practical challenges. It will be taught through a combination of lectures, practical sessions, workshops and self directed learning.

This practical will be assessed via three methods: continual assessment to assess understanding of practical skills (experimental, technical and computational/quantitative statistics), a practical skills observational assessment to improve research and experimental skills and a written scientific abstract to assess overall understanding and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Introduction to practical & experimental skills within Life Sciences. Covering topics such as the use of basic laboratory equipment, practical skills, scientific measurements, data handling, health & safety and ethics.

Topic 2: Handling & measurements of Model Organisms. Covering topics such as handling of model organisms such as zebra fish, microscopy and application to health and disease

Topic 3: Measurements at the molecular level. Covering topics such as stock concentration preparation, serial dilutions, standard curve creation & calculations

Topic 4: Microbiological techniques. Covering topics such as Aseptic technique, antibiotic resistance, bacterial handling and microbial identification.

Topic 5: Media Preparation & Acids & Bases. Covering topics such as pH buffering, creation of media and solutions

Topic 6: Mutation & Cell Viability. Covering topics such as dose response (LD50s), dilution, concentration calculations and toxicology testing.

Topic 7: Protein concentration determination. Covering topics such as protein solution preparation, determination of unknown concentrations, Bradford/protein assays, spectrophotometry

Topic 8: Introduction to Cell Biology & cell surface interactions. Covering topics such as molecular interactions and multicellularity, plate assays; Microscopy: counting cell populations, examining cells and surface charge;

Topic 9: Histology. Covering topics such as muscle histology, tissue staining, visualisation and microscopy


Statistical, data interpretation & data visualisation skills to be implemented may include topics such as:

Topic 1: Introduction to Excel and R Coding

Topic 2: Manipulating numbers & data

Topic 3: Units and Conversion.

Topic 4: Molarities, concentrations and serial dilutions.

Topic 5: Linear equations and linear regression.

Topic 5: Non-linear equations and logarithms,

Topic 6: Descriptive Statistics

Topic 7: Hypothesis building and testing (Inferential Statistics)
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also e corporate application of numeracy & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies. All asynchronous content will be accompanied by formative, dynamic quizzes that allow students to practice the practical application of quantitative skills encountered.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 5

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. These comprise of multiple sessions of active learning which focus on the assessment tasks/real world research, data analysis and simulations.
Attendance Recorded: Yes


The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Life Sciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated.



Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.



Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the life sciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.



Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The competency assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills, continual learning and development and appreciation of the principles of good lab practice, ethics and safety. Continual assessment will allow students to implement theoretical, numerical and data handling skills to applied scientific problems that have been covered within the practical. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific abstract is highly authentic for practical application and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.



Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.



Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.



Global citizenship: Life Sciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:

1. Continuous assessment in the form of portfolio consisting of post lab online tests (weighting 40%) which assesses the student's relevant academic knowledge, as well as enquiry-based analytical skills (Research connected teaching, Digital Fluency - Liverpool Curriculum). Open book and resit not allowed.

2. Practical skills assessment (30%) based on skills acquired in practical sessions, formative feedback given immediately and verbally, multiple attempts throughout semester (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

3. Abstract writing (weighting 30%) based on the skills to evaluate and interpret and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
This practical module is the first experience of life science practical and quantitative skills for students and aims to provide applied and theoretical experience in basic practical techniques currently used across the Life Sciences disciplines. The module is designed so that students acquire a wide range of experimental, analytical & problem-solving skills that will be required for other practical modules throughout the degree and will begin to lay the foundations for their Year 3 research project and of subsequent careers. It aims to develop good lab practices, experimental design and interpretation of results, using fundamental quantitative skills to handle and analyse corresponding data that has been acquired by the students.

The module comprises of physical practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and quantitative workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand methodologies, undertake research science safely and apply research methods to coaligned theoretical content. They will also be able to communicate their research findings. This practical will be assessed via three methods: continual assessment to assess understanding of practical skills (experimental, technical and computational/quantitative statistics), a practical skills observational assessment to improve research and experimental skills and a written scientific abstract to assess overall understanding and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To enhance students' practical skills in key experimental techniques, data collection, data manipulation/visualisation, interpretation, and analyses.

2. To develop a further understanding of theoretical knowledge in the context of practical skills and exercises.

3. To demonstrate the relevance of practical skills across all biological disciplines and explain the importance of observing good laboratory practice.

4. To develop the essential quantitative, numerical, and digital skills required to be competent Life Scientists.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This is the first practical module that students will take in the School of Life Sciences. The variety of experimental, quantitative and transferable skills that students acquire will be required for future practical modules that they will take in Year 1 Semester 2, during Year 2 and will prepare them for their Year 3 research project and for their subsequent career. This module is designed to teach the basic multidisciplinary skills required in the field of life sciences, provide an understanding of basic lab practice and safety and to allow application of theoretical knowledge to solve practical challenges. It will be taught through a combination of lectures, practical sessions, workshops and self directed learning.

This practical will be assessed via three methods: continual assessment to assess understanding of practical skills (experimental, technical and computational/quantitative statistics), a practical skills observational assessment to improve research and experimental skills and a written scientific abstract to assess overall understanding and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Introduction to practical & experimental skills within Life Sciences. Covering topics such as the use of basic laboratory equipment, practical skills, scientific measurements, data handling, health & safety and ethics.

Topic 2: Handling & measurements of Model Organisms. Covering topics such as handling of model organisms such as zebra fish, microscopy and application to health and disease

Topic 3: Measurements at the molecular level. Covering topics such as stock concentration preparation, serial dilutions, standard curve creation & calculations

Topic 4: Microbiological techniques. Covering topics such as Aseptic technique, antibiotic resistance, bacterial handling and microbial identification.

Topic 5: Media Preparation & Acids & Bases. Covering topics such as pH buffering, creation of media and solutions

Topic 6: Mutation & Cell Viability. Covering topics such as dose response (LD50s), dilution, concentration calculations and toxicology testing.

Topic 7: Protein concentration determination. Covering topics such as protein solution preparation, determination of unknown concentrations, Bradford/protein assays, spectrophotometry

Topic 8: Introduction to Cell Biology & cell surface interactions. Covering topics such as molecular interactions and multicellularity, plate assays; Microscopy: counting cell populations, examining cells and surface charge;

Topic 9: Histology. Covering topics such as muscle histology, tissue staining, visualisation and microscopy


Statistical, data interpretation & data visualisation skills to be implemented may include topics such as:

Topic 1: Introduction to Excel and R Coding

Topic 2: Manipulating numbers & data

Topic 3: Units and Conversion.

Topic 4: Molarities, concentrations and serial dilutions.

Topic 5: Linear equations and linear regression.

Topic 5: Non-linear equations and logarithms,

Topic 6: Descriptive Statistics

Topic 7: Hypothesis building and testing (Inferential Statistics)
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also e corporate application of numeracy & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies. All asynchronous content will be accompanied by formative, dynamic quizzes that allow students to practice the practical application of quantitative skills encountered.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 5

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. These comprise of multiple sessions of active learning which focus on the assessment tasks/real world research, data analysis and simulations.
Attendance Recorded: Yes


The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Life Sciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated.



Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.



Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the life sciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.



Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The competency assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills, continual learning and development and appreciation of the principles of good lab practice, ethics and safety. Continual assessment will allow students to implement theoretical, numerical and data handling skills to applied scientific problems that have been covered within the practical. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific abstract is highly authentic for practical application and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.



Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.



Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.



Global citizenship: Life Sciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:

1. Continuous assessment in the form of portfolio consisting of post lab online tests (weighting 40%) which assesses the student's relevant academic knowledge, as well as enquiry-based analytical skills (Research connected teaching, Digital Fluency - Liverpool Curriculum). Open book and resit not allowed.

2. Practical skills assessment (30%) based on skills acquired in practical sessions, formative feedback given immediately and verbally, multiple attempts throughout semester (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

3. Abstract writing (weighting 30%) based on the skills to evaluate and interpret and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

2. Practical skills assessment (30%) based on skills acquired in practical sessions, formative feedback given immediately and verbally, multiple attempts throughout semester (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

3. Abstract writing (weighting 30%) based on the skills to evaluate and interpret and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO1 Record procedures and protocols for experiments relating to Life Sciences and generate, evaluate and interpret qualitative and quantitative data.

Liverpool campus · Semester 1

Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO5 Introduce students to the use of basic digital tools for handling data and visualising data.
